FacilityName: Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP: Orange Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Orange facility is a high-density polyethylene (HDPE) plant owned by Chevron Phillips Chemical Company and is located in Orange, Texas in Orange County. It processes ethylene feed to produce high-density plastic pellets which are then shipped by rail to other consumers. The Orange facility consists of multiple units that are handled as separate Process Hazard Analyses, including CPF, GPO, G-Line, H-Line, ERU, and Utilities. For purposes of the RMP, the CPF, H-Line and ERU were combined into a single reported process (Process 1) and the GPO and G-Line were combined into a single report process (Process 2). Note that the ERU connects to both the CPF and the GPO but was included with the CPF as the main process unit.



The Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP, Orange Plant has a fundamental commitment to

worker and public safety as demonstrated by a strict adherence to Operational Excellence principles and procedures. Operating in a safe and environmentally protective manner are values held above all others. The Orange Plant is focused on preventing process-related incidents that might affect plant personnel, visitors, the community or the environment. The Process Safety Management (PSM) program and Risk Management Program (RMP) demonstrates this focused commitment. The PSM program involves the application of management systems and performance management practices to control process hazards through objectives, programs, procedures, audits, evaluations, and training that considers safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.



Safety and environmental incidents are to be reported immediately and followed directly by an

incident investigation which will develop the root causes and actions to be taken to avoid similar

incidents in the future. Investigations will be conducted with the objective of determining the causes and prevention of future incidents.



The knowledge that is gained from accident/incident reports, maintenanc

e records, case histories,

and trend analysis of incidents will provide basic information and potential changes that can be used to help further prevent catastrophic events. To help manage this information, Chevron Phillips Chemical Company has implemented a corporate computer-based system to track and share environmental, health and safety recommendations, changes and incidents.



Chemical-Specific Prevention:



The processes at the Orange Plant have hazards that must be managed to help ensure continued safe operation. The Accident Prevention Program summarized previously is applied to all OSHA PSM / EPA RMP covered processes at the plant. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors. In addition to the Accident Prevention Program activities, the Orange Plant has safety features on many of its units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (i.e. mitigate) a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:



?    Release Detection.

?    Release Containment/Control.

?    Periodic inspection of process equipment.

?    Inspections by Operators each shift.

?    Routine leak detection and repair program for all system components.

?    Remotely activated valves to isolate and limit release.

?    Emergency equipment shutdown systems that are activated automatically, locally or remotely.

?    Diked and sloped area with sump for spill containment.

?    Relief devices to prevent system overpressure.

?    Automatic overfill prevention instrumentation.

?    Process Relief Valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate releases.

?    Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated).

?    Redundant equipment and instrumentation.

?    Equipment designed and constructed to comply with industry codes, standards, and practices.

?    Internal and external audits to verify conforma

nce with regulatory and Company standards.

?    Release Mitigation.

?    Established Emergency Response Plan.

?    Emergency Alarm System.

?    Automatic water sprinkler system and fire hydrants with nozzles in specific areas.

?    Fire Suppression and Extinguishing Systems.

?    Mobile emergency response equipment.

?    Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).

?    Trained Emergency Responders onsite 24 hours/day

?    Communications link to offsite response teams such as the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC)

THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED AT THE FACILITY:



The Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP Orange Plant is located in Orange, Texas and operates two reactors that produce high density polyethylene (HDPE). 



The HDPE manufacturing process uses various regulated flammable chemicals such as ethylene, isobutane, propane, hydrogen, and isopentane to produce HDPE

 

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:



The following is a summary of the general accident prevention programs in place at the Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP, Orange Plant. The Orange Plant is an OSHA PSM regulated

facility. The elements of the Orange Plant's PSM program / OSHA PSM standard have been in

place since 1992, which essentially mirror the prevention program requirement of the EPA's RMP standard.



Employee Participation



The intent of employee participation is to ensure that Orange Plant employees are informed,

consulted and involved in all aspects of process safety management. Examples of employee

participation range from reviewing Process Safety Information (PSI) and Standard Operating

Procedures (SOPs) to serving on Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) teams.

The Orange Plant also uses other processes such as company communication tools, Reinforcement Based Safety (RBS), and OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) to keep employees engaged and provide periodic reminders to the employees that their process safety concerns and suggestion

creasing the likelihood of a potential incident. IPL Analysis provides the risk assessment methodology for the Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) which is an integral part of the PSM program. If an action item arises from the analysis it will be managed and tracked to completion.



Operating Procedures



Written standard operating procedures (SOP) provide clear instructions for the safe operation and

control of the process and associated equipment. SOPs are readily accessible to operations

personnel in the control room and all other employees via an electronic delivery system. The SOPs address various phases of operation, such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and subsequent startup. SOPs also address safety and health considerations and information on Safe Work Practices. Revisions to SOPs may be prompted as a result of management of change, process hazard analysis, an annual review of SOPs or input from employees who may use the SOPs.



Training



The Orange Plant has implemented a comprehensive training program for its employees, especially those involved in operating a process. Operator training has been developed to equip operators with the knowledge and skill necessary to safely and proficiently perform their job duties. This training emphasizes specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks. Written tests, observation, demonstration, and peer evaluations are used to verify the training. Refresher training/certification is provided every three years to operations personnel. Training in safe work practices is provided to employees during new employee safety orientation, annual safety training, special classes, computer based training, and electronic notices of change.

Process Safety Information (PSI)



The Orange plant compiles and maintains written process safety information to enable both the

employer and employee to effectively identify and understand the hazards posed by the process.

Written PSI provides employees with baseline information to identify hazards of the chemicals used or produced in the process, information about the technology of the process, and information about the equipment in the process. This PSI provides the foundation for performing the unit Process Hazards Analyses, developing operating procedures, and determining the applicability of management of change.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)



A Process Hazard Analysis is a systematic evaluation of all aspects of the process (equipment, chemicals, technology, and procedures) to identify the potential hazards associated with the processing and handling of highly hazardous chemicals. PHAs are performed on existing and new units in all of the Orange Plant's processes. The Checklist and Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), or other appropriate equivalent methodologies, were used to perform the PHAs on each covered process at the Orange plant. A PHA results in action items (findings/recommendations) that identify and address perceived potential hazards. The action items are prioritized for management and employee resolution using the scheme below:

The Orange Plant uses Layers of Protection Analysis methodology (commonly referred to as LOPA) to integrate process risk management into a unified, comprehensive program. Independent Protection Layers (IPLs) are systems used to mitigate serious environmental and process safety risk, identified during the process hazard analysis. IPLs include specific and identified standard operating procedures, alarms with operator response, safety instrumented systems, emergency shutdown systems, and protective devices. IPLs can be viewed as one of the first lines of defense against a potential incident by de

nds, major renovations, construction, demolition, equipment installation or specialty work on or adjacent to covered processes. Thus, their actions may have an influence on process safety. The Orange Plant informs contractors of known potential fire, explosion or toxic release hazards related to the contractor's work and the process as well as the emergency action plan, safe work practices and sign-in/sign-out requirements for the Orange Plant. The contract employer is responsible for assuring that each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform his/her job.





Mechanical Integrity



The intent of the mechanical integrity program is to provide a management system that ensures: (1) the equipment is maintained in a manner to prevent or minimize the consequences of a catastrophic release of a highly hazardous chemical and (2) the equipment is maintained by trained and qualified personnel to assure its continued integrity. Mechanical integrity covered equipment at the Orange Plant includes the following type of equipment: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping, valves, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. The basic aspects of the mechanical integrity system include: (1) design and construction requirements; (2) preventive maintenance practices; (3) testing and inspection; (4) repair, modification and alteration procedures; and (5) inspector and craftsman training and qualifications.



Safe Work Practices



The Orange Plant has many safe work practices that promote worker and process safety. Examples of these include (1) hot work permits to control work involving flame or spark-producing operations; (2) confined space entry permits to ensure adequate safety precautions have been taken prior to entering vessels, tanks and other confined spaces; (3) lockout/tagout procedures to guarantee isolation of energy sources prior to working on equipment; and (4) pressure-relief device (PRD) removal proce

dures to ensure adequate alternate relief paths are available prior to removal of any PRD and (5) interlock and alarm bypassing procedures to ensure that critical process controls are managed properly. These procedures, along with others, form a system to help make certain that operations and maintenance activities are performed in a safe manner. 



Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review



The Orange Plant has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes. Changes may introduce new hazards or compromise safeguards incorporated into the original design of the process and must be reviewed prior to their implementation. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process-operating conditions), software, procedures (including operating, maintenance, and safe work) and emergency procedures be properly reviewed for potential hazards and authorized before being implemented. This system requires that any change executed address the following: the technical basis for the proposed change; the impact of the change on safety and health; modifications to operating procedures; necessary time period for change; and authorization requirements for the proposed change. Affected process safety information (e.g., mechanical, electrical/instrument, chemical, and operating limits) and procedures (e.g., operating, maintenance, and safe work) are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided necessary training on the change. The Orange Plant conducts a Pre-startup Safety Review for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. A PSSR is conducted for the following types of changes: equipment, facilities, and/or process chemicals, technology, and software. The PSSR serves as a final verification prior to the introduction of highly hazardous chemicals into the process at a new facility and conducted prior

to start-up, commissioning, or engagement of the change, for existing, modified facilities. The PSSR must confirm the following: a PHA has been performed for new facilities and that PHA recommendations have been resolved; MOC requirements have been executed for changes to modified facilities; construction and equipment installation is in accordance with design specifications; training of each employee involved in operating a process has been completed; and, safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.



Incident Investigation



Incidents, which resulted in or reasonably could have resulted in a catastrophic release of a highly hazardous chemical, are investigated by a cross-section of plant personnel. The composition of investigation teams varies with the complexity of the incident, but the underlying philosophy is one of employee/contractor involvement, as appropriate. Once the results of the incident investigation are available, incidents including findings and recommended actions are summarized and communicated throughout the facility. The full incident investigation report is available to any employee/contractor



Compliance Audits



The Orange Plant conducts compliance audits to periodically evaluate the effectiveness of the PSM Program; to ensure that each program element complies with the standard; and to ascertain whether the elements from internal procedures and practices are adequate and are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years. The audit team is comprised of a variety of disciplines who use a set of self-audit checklists based on the OSHA PSM and EPA RMP standards. Audit findings and responses are entered and maintained in a computer-based tracking system. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:



The RMP rule requires facilities to compile a 5-Year Accident History for all

RMP regulated substances in covered processes at the facility.  As part of the ongoing PSM Program, the facility documents and tracks all incidents and near-misses that occur within the facility



RMP requires facilities to report any incident from a covered process involving a regulated substance and resulting in any of the following:

?    Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage

?    Offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, or environmental damage

The CPChem Orange Plant had no RMP reportable incident in the five years prior to the submittal of this RMP.  



THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:



The Orange Plant operates an extensive emergency response program to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The Orange Plant has several written documents, which detail the actions to be taken in response to an unwanted release of a highly hazardous chemical. General Plant Safety Rules provide basic instructions to employees for reporting and responding to an emergency. The Orange Plant Emergency Action Plan further provides detailed instructions and information used by essential personnel with regard to the emergency planning and response systems that are implemented at the Orange Plant.



The Emergency Action Plan is developed and updated by a cross-section of plant personnel under the direction of the Safety Department. A significant part of the Emergency Action Plan is the Orange Plant Emergency Response Team. This team provides a significant part of all emergency response services for the facility. This team is comprised of employees who voluntarily participate as members of the team. Membership requires participation in a rigorous training and qualification program. Once qualified, each team member is expected to respond to emergency alarms while at work or if called out after their normal work shift.



The program consists of procedures for responding to various emergencies, including a small

in

cidental emergency, plant-wide emergency, an external emergency, a hurricane or severe weather emergency, and a bomb threat. The Incident Command System (ICS) is used to manage all emergency response situations. The Orange Plant Emergency Response Team, a volunteer group of trained employees, responds to all plant emergencies to help minimize loss of life, property and to provide emergency medical care to the injured. Trained Emergency Responders are onsite 24 hours per day.



The Orange Plant is a member of the Orange County LEPC (Local Emergency Planning

Committee), SNC (Sabine Neches Chiefs), and STAN (Southeast Texas Alerting Network).



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:



Continuous improvement in safety and environmental performance will be achieved through several practices including employee safety processes, Tenets of Operation guiding principles, Operational Excellence System, and other employee involvement programs. Planned changes to improve safety at the Orange Plant are reviewed and adjusted annually. Improvements are also included in the yearly budgets and incorporated into the performance management systems / practices throughout the organization. These planned changes include, but are not limited to safety related capital projects, safety programs / initiatives, procedure improvements, and SOP validations.
